articles.headline: Senior Hezbollah Leader Is Killed in Beirut in Israeli Airstrike
articles.snippet: The attack, which Lebanese officials said killed at least 14 and injured more than 60, stoked fears Israel is driving toward a full-blown war on its northern border, even as the fight in Gaza goes on.
articles.abstract: The attack, which Lebanese officials said killed at least 14 and injured more than 60, stoked fears Israel is driving toward a full-blown war on its northern border, even as the fight in Gaza goes on.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israeli fighter jets bombed an apartment building in Beirut’s densely populated southern suburbs on Friday in what the military called an attack on Hezbollah militants, including a senior commander who was wanted in the deadly 1983 bombings of the U.S. embassy and U.S. Marine Corps barracks in Beirut.
articles.byline: By Liam Stack, Euan Ward, Aaron Boxerman and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: After Apple, Jony Ive Is Building an Empire of His Own
articles.snippet: Five years after leaving Apple, the iPhone designer is forging a new life in San Francisco, one imaginative building at a time.
articles.abstract: Five years after leaving Apple, the iPhone designer is forging a new life in San Francisco, one imaginative building at a time.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five years to the week after he walked away from the top job designing the iPhone, Jony Ive leaned over a hulking model of a San Francisco city block. The dozen buildings, with each brick carved to scale in Alder wood, had become a prototype for his future.

articles.headline: As President, Trump Demanded Investigations of Foes. He Often Got Them.
articles.snippet: He has threatened to target his perceived enemies if elected again. A look at his time in the White House shows how readily he could do so.
articles.abstract: He has threatened to target his perceived enemies if elected again. A look at his time in the White House shows how readily he could do so.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the spring of 2018 and President Donald J. Trump, faced with an accelerating inquiry into his campaign’s ties to Russia, was furious that the Justice Department was reluctant to strike back at those he saw as his enemies.

articles.headline: Where Joy Meets Anger: Harris and Trump Battle for Undecided Voters
articles.snippet: The allegiances of this group of voters — roughly three million people in seven battleground states — are up for grabs, and polling shows they’re pessimistic about the country’s future.
articles.abstract: The allegiances of this group of voters — roughly three million people in seven battleground states — are up for grabs, and polling shows they’re pessimistic about the country’s future.
articles.lead_paragraph: Devon Howard is not feeling the joy.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Swan, Jennifer Medina, Ruth Igielnik and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Attacks on Hezbollah Alter Balance of Power in Long-Running Fight
articles.snippet: A focus on mutual deterrence had kept intermittent clashes along the Lebanon-Israel border from spiraling into a major war. That changed this past week.
articles.abstract: A focus on mutual deterrence had kept intermittent clashes along the Lebanon-Israel border from spiraling into a major war. That changed this past week.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the second time in less than two months, Israel located and killed Hezbollah’s most senior and secretive military figures as they held covert meetings near Beirut. And in between those strikes, Israel incapacitated hundreds, if not thousands, of the group’s rank-and-file members by remotely blowing up their pagers and walkie-talkies.

articles.headline: How a U.S. Ally Uses Aid as a Cover in War
articles.snippet: The United Arab Emirates is expanding a covert campaign to back a winner in Sudan’s civil war. Waving the banner of the Red Crescent, it is also smuggling weapons and deploying drones.
articles.abstract: The United Arab Emirates is expanding a covert campaign to back a winner in Sudan’s civil war. Waving the banner of the Red Crescent, it is also smuggling weapons and deploying drones.
articles.lead_paragraph: The drones soar over the vast deserts along the Sudanese border, guiding weapons convoys that smuggle illicit arms to fighters accused of widespread atrocities and ethnic cleansing.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh and Christoph Koettl

articles.headline: How Trump Could Upend Taxation in America
articles.snippet: With slogans and in social-media posts, the former president has dribbled out ideas that, together, would fundamentally change how taxes are collected in the U.S.
articles.abstract: With slogans and in social-media posts, the former president has dribbled out ideas that, together, would fundamentally change how taxes are collected in the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the start of the summer, when former President Donald J. Trump visited Republicans on Capitol Hill, he hinted at a vision for a vastly different tax system than what the United States has employed for decades.

articles.headline: Harris Cracked Down on Violent Offenders; Showed Leniency on Less Serious Crime
articles.snippet: Her record as a prosecutor navigating both paths has left her open to criticism that she either betrayed liberal ideals or prioritized them over law and order.
articles.abstract: Her record as a prosecutor navigating both paths has left her open to criticism that she either betrayed liberal ideals or prioritized them over law and order.
articles.lead_paragraph: From the moment that Kamala Harris took her place among 57 counterparts at the 2004 California District Attorneys Association annual conference, it was an open question how, if at all, the first Black, Asian American and female D.A. in the state’s history would fit in.

articles.headline: The Tumult That Transformed Racquet, the Tennis Magazine
articles.snippet: The indie magazine Racquet aims to become a major player in the business of tennis — after a messy dispute between its two founders.
articles.abstract: The indie magazine Racquet aims to become a major player in the business of tennis — after a messy dispute between its two founders.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. Open looked like fun and games for Racquet magazine.

articles.headline: The Politics of Motherhood Become a Campaign-Trail Cudgel
articles.snippet: The presidential race has exposed a fault line in American political culture over the deeply personal decision to have children.
articles.abstract: The presidential race has exposed a fault line in American political culture over the deeply personal decision to have children.
articles.lead_paragraph: She is not humble. She has no stake in the future of the country. She and other childless women are looking down on Americans who have chosen to reproduce.

articles.headline: Israel and Hezbollah Threaten to Hit Harder, Raising Fears of All-Out War
articles.snippet: A leader of the Iranian-backed militia said its latest barrage was “just the beginning,” and an Israeli military official said, “Our strikes will intensify.”
articles.abstract: A leader of the Iranian-backed militia said its latest barrage was “just the beginning,” and an Israeli military official said, “Our strikes will intensify.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and a top Hezbollah leader vowed on Sunday to increase the intensity of their cross-border attacks, raising fears that the renewed conflict could escalate into all-out war.
articles.byline: By Adam Rasgon, Euan Ward, Hwaida Saad and Ken Belson

articles.headline: In a First Among Christians, Young Men Are More Religious Than Young Women
articles.snippet: At Grace Church in Waco, Texas, the Generation Z gender divide can be seen in the pews. It has the potential to reshape both politics and family life.
articles.abstract: At Grace Church in Waco, Texas, the Generation Z gender divide can be seen in the pews. It has the potential to reshape both politics and family life.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a beautiful Sunday morning in early September, dozens of young men in Waco, Texas, started their day at Grace Church.

articles.headline: U.S. Research Aided Chinese Military Technology, House Republicans Say
articles.snippet: A congressional report argues that Beijing has exploited ties with American universities to advance technologically, and that further guardrails are needed.
articles.abstract: A congressional report argues that Beijing has exploited ties with American universities to advance technologically, and that further guardrails are needed.
articles.lead_paragraph: A House committee focused on threats from China argues in a new report that U.S. federal research funding had helped to advance Chinese technologies with military applications, fueling a potential national security rival to the United States.

articles.headline: Trump Shows Signs of Strength in Sun Belt Battlegrounds, Polls Find
articles.snippet: New polls from The New York Times and Siena College showed Donald J. Trump ahead in Arizona and leading in tight races in Georgia and North Carolina.
articles.abstract: New polls from The New York Times and Siena College showed Donald J. Trump ahead in Arizona and leading in tight races in Georgia and North Carolina.
articles.lead_paragraph: Voters across the Sun Belt say that Donald J. Trump improved their lives when he was president — and worry that a Kamala Harris White House would not — setting the stage for an extraordinarily competitive contest in three key states, according to the latest polls from The New York Times and Siena College.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney, Ruth Igielnik and Camille Baker

articles.headline: Biden Administration Proposes Ban on Chinese Software in Vehicles
articles.snippet: Federal officials acknowledged that few Chinese vehicles were on U.S. roads now, but said that the administration wanted to take proactive measures to strengthen national security.
articles.abstract: Federal officials acknowledged that few Chinese vehicles were on U.S. roads now, but said that the administration wanted to take proactive measures to strengthen national security.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration announced a sweeping initiative on Monday to ban Chinese-developed software from internet-connected cars in the United States, justifying the move on national security grounds. The action is intended to prevent Chinese intelligence agencies from monitoring the movements of Americans or using the vehicles’ electronics as a pathway into the U.S. electric grid or other critical infrastructure.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Madeleine Ngo and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Will A.I. Be a Bust? A Wall Street Skeptic Rings the Alarm.
articles.snippet: Jim Covello, Goldman Sachs’s head of stock research, warned that building too much of what the world doesn’t need “typically ends badly.”
articles.abstract: Jim Covello, Goldman Sachs’s head of stock research, warned that building too much of what the world doesn’t need “typically ends badly.”
articles.lead_paragraph: As Jim Covello’s car barreled up Highway 101 from San Jose to San Francisco this month, he counted the billboards about artificial intelligence. The nearly 40 signs he passed, including one that promoted something called Writer Enterprise AI and another for Speech AI, were fresh evidence, he thought, of an economic bubble.
